care.watering: Water when top 2-3 inches of soil are dry. Typically once per week in growing season, every 2 weeks in winter.
care.sunlight: Bright, indirect light. Can tolerate some shade but growth will slow. Avoid direct sunlight which can scorch leaves.
care.pruning: Prune in spring to control size and shape. Remove dead or damaged leaves anytime. Use clean, sharp scissors.

troubleshooting.symptoms: Leaves turning yellow, especially lower leaves. Soil feels wet or waterlogged.
troubleshooting.solution: Overwatering is the likely cause. Allow soil to dry out between waterings. Check drainage holes are not blocked. Reduce watering frequency.

troubleshooting.symptoms: Leaf edges and tips turning brown and crispy. Soil feels dry.
troubleshooting.solution: Underwatering or low humidity. Increase watering frequency slightly. Mist leaves regularly or use a humidifier. Ensure pot has adequate drainage.

troubleshooting.symptoms: Leaves drooping and looking limp. Plant appears sad.
troubleshooting.solution: If soil is dry: Water thoroughly until water drains from bottom. If soil is wet: Root rot possible, reduce watering and check roots for mushiness.

troubleshooting.symptoms: Dark or light spots appearing on leaves. May have yellow halos.
troubleshooting.solution: Could be fungal infection from overwatering or bacterial spot. Remove affected leaves, improve air circulation, avoid getting water on leaves, and reduce humidity.

troubleshooting.symptoms: Visible insects, sticky residue, or webbing on leaves.
troubleshooting.solution: Check for spider mites, mealybugs, or scale. Wipe leaves with soapy water or neem oil solution. Isolate plant from others. Repeat treatment weekly.

faqs.q: How often should I water my Monstera?
faqs.a: Water when the top 2-3 inches of soil feel dry to the touch. This is typically once per week during the growing season and every 2 weeks in winter.

faqs.q: Why are my Monstera leaves not splitting?
faqs.a: Young leaves don't split. Mature plants need bright indirect light and proper care to develop fenestrations. Be patient and ensure adequate light.

faqs.q: Can Monstera survive in low light?
faqs.a: Monstera can tolerate low light but will grow much slower and may not develop leaf splits. Bright, indirect light is ideal for healthy growth.
